preparation.prep_1_intro:
You get news that century long enemy Kingdom (Kingdom Name) is planning to seize your Kingdom. However, due to a bad harvest season, the Kingdom is lacking in resources, so your only option are to raid nearby weaker Kingdoms.
You have been tasked with leading and documenting.

prep_1_dec_1.prompt: You are given a choice between sending new solider recruits into two different education paths. One focuses on range while the other focuses on close combat. Which education path do you send your first wave of soldiers?

answer_1.outcome: Your soldiers become reliable with a bow. Stamp 2 archers

answer_2.outcome: your soldiers become skilled with a sword. Stamp 2 swordsmen

prep_1_dec_2.prompt:
You are given a choice between two training programs. The first trains horses to battle alongside your soldiers, while the other trains the physical abilities of your soldiers. 
Which training program do you pick?

answer_1.outcome: You can now have your best soldiers ride into battle. Stamp 2 horses

answer_2.outcome: Your soldiers become much more capable. Add the strength stamp to your army

prep_1_dec_3.prompt: You are given the option of bulking up your defense lines or bulking up your offensive lines with a grant from the local lord. Where do you put the money?

answer_1.outcome: Your army grows impenetrable. Stamp 2 Shieldmen

answer_2.outcome: Your army strikes fear into enemies. Stamp 2 swordsmen

prep_1_dec_4.prompt: Due to the poor harvest season, leather for shields and bows are limited. With what leather is given to the army, do you put it towards producing shields or producing bows?

answer_1.outcome: Your kingdom's crest is burned onto the leather covers. Stamp 2 Shieldmen

answer_2.outcome: The leather is used to create a solid grip. Stamp 2 archers

prep_1_outro.prompt:
It is now the time to pick your battle. Two Kingdoms are set before you, both with resources needed for your Kingdom’s protection. 
The first Kingdom (name) resides in the flat fields, rich of crops and farm animals. They are known for their archery and speed, adapting to the open and flat geography.
The second Kingdom (name) rests on the rocky shores, rich in metals and oceanic resources. They’re known for their close combat and power, useful to living in the uneven geography.

answer_1.outcome: It has been decided. Stamp the enemy's crest in yellow

answer_2.outcome: It has been decided.  Stamp the enemy's crest in green

battle_1_decision_1.1.prompt:
You inform your army of the raiding of (Kingdom Name), and you waste no time as your troops make the journey. 
You see the Kingdom from many miles away, visible with the flat openness of the fields. Your army faces the front entrance, guarded by the Kingdom’s own army of Archers.

 STAMP an enemy Archer on the right side of cell in (color) ink

 Do you order your army to ambush and attack the enemy Archers before they have the chance to shoot, or do you sneak in through another entrance?

answer_1.outcome:
You order your army to ambush the guarding Archers. The enemy Archers see your army as you approach on the open fields, drawing their bows and shooting quick.
In the open fields, with no protection or ways of evading, the incoming arrows hits a large chunk of your troops. They’re weakened by these injuries.

STAMP arrows pointing left on the left side
STAMP weakness
answer_1.outcome_2:
You order your army to ambush the guarding Archers. The enemy Archers see your army as you approach on the open fields, drawing their bows and shooting quick.
With the speed and agility of the Horses, your troops are able to evade the in-coming arrows.

STAMP arrows pointing down on the left side

answer_2.outcome: You order your army to avoid the main entrance and sneak in through one of the outer entrances used for accessing the outer wheat fields. Through the tall wheat, your troops sneaks through, slipping in easily.

answer_1.outcome:
You order your troop to charge in for a surprise attack. However, the rocky and uneven stone ground is foreign on your troops feet. You watch as they each loose their footing and trip.
Unfortunately, your troops weren’t trained for this. Even with the horses, your men (and horses) are unable to recover from their trips. Your troops, scraped and hurt by the rocks, still continues to charge, but it’s clear they’re weak to their injuries.
answer_1.outcome_2:
You order your troop to charge in for a surprise attack. However, the rocky and uneven stone ground is foreign on your troops feet. You watch as they each loose their footing and trip.
Luckily, your troops were trained for this. Their physical training allowing your troops to quickly recover from the trip, brushing off their injuries and continuing to charge forwards.

battle_1_decision_2.1.prompt:
Through the wave of arrows, your troops reach closer to the enemy Archers, now face to face with them. Now in close reach, your close range troops are able to attack. 
You’re given two options.

answer_1.option: Send your archers to raid the kingdom.
answer_1.outcome:
You follow along with your Archers, raiding one of the Kingdom’s inner towns, rich in wheat useful for food. This town has a large dried grain storage house, currently being raided by you and your Archers.
 STAMP

answer_2.option: Keep all your troops together to attack.
answer_2.outcome:
As your troops continue to fight the enemy soldiers, you see more enemy soldiers from inside the Kingdom start to approach, most likely alerted during the arrow rain. 

STAMP

battle_1_decision_2.2.prompt: Now inside, you decide to start raiding before enemies notice your invasion. Do you...

answer_1.outcome: Deciding to keep your army together, your numbers are enough to start raiding a decently sized town within the Kingdom.

answer_2.outcome: You decide to split your troops up into small group to cover more area. Following one of the larger groups, you find yourselves in a small town, with a small town center.

battle_1_decision_2.3.prompt:
Even with the struggle of the ground, your army gets closer to the enemies guarding the entrance. They don’t see you approach fast enough to use the rocks to their advantage, instead facing your troops at face level. They’re equipped with long swords and thick shields.
You’re given two options on how to advance.

answer_1.outcome: You command your Archers to shoot at the enemy lines, hoping to use the slight distance between to your advantage. However, your arrows are no match for the shields, almost bouncing off.

answer_2.outcome: You command your Shield-men to push through the enemy lines, using their shields to block the attacks of the swords. With your Shield-men on the defensive, your troops are able to force their way into the Kingdom.

battle_1_decision_3.1.prompt:
Enemy troops located inside the Kingdom gets news of your raiding, and a handful of Archers on horseback ambushes you in the storage house. 
Do you set the storage on fire, allowing for an escape but losing the grain inside, or do you use force to attack back?

answer_1.outcome:
You pull out a match stick from your pocket, striking it against one of the wooden support beam. You toss it into the piles of dried grain, seeing it catch a-blaze. As the fire starts to spread, it scares the enemy horses, allowing you and your Archers to escape the burning storage house.

STAMP

While none of your Archers looses their life, you are unable to continue to raid the town. The enemy Archers quickly recovers and their keen eye makes it impossible for you to continue to raid the town. It’s likely word has gone out as well, stopping your troops to raid anymore.

answer_2.outcome:
You order your Archers to fight back quickly. Your Archers, fast on their feet and bows, out-shoots the enemy Archers before they could ready their bows. Their horses are scared away from the arrows.
You and your troops are able to quickly raid the piles of grain from the storage. It’s enough grain to supply bread to your whole army.

STAMP
answer_2.outcome_2:
You order your Archers to fight back quickly. Your Archers, injured from the arrows earlier, struggles to pull their bows in time. Your Archers are shot one by one, unable to defend themselves. You’re able to flee from the storage house.
Grouping back with the rest of your troop outside, you choose to draw back. The news have gotten out of your raiding, and more enemy Archers are making their way to the front entrance.

STAMP

battle_1_decision_3.2.prompt:
They have yet to get within bow and arrow range. Your army won’t be able to combat all of them at once, so you have no choice but to send one of your force to take care of the incoming enemies.

 Who do you send in?

answer_1.outcome:
You order your Swordmen to take care of the incoming enemy troops. The Swordmen, jumping onto horseback, quickly charges at them, evading the arrows similar to before. They’re able to get face to face and attack, too close for the enemy Archers to shoot more. 
You see those enemy Archers fall as your Swordmen takes them out. Too far away to hear anymore commands, the Swordmen decide to do some raiding as you and the others continue to fight the enemy troops outside the Kingdom.

STAMP
answer_1.outcome_2:
You order your Swordmen to take care of the incoming enemy troops. They make their way over, but with their injuries from the arrows earlier, they are slower and clumsier. The Swordmen get spotted easily, and lacking the speed, they get shot down easily.

STAMP

Without a portion of your army, you’re unable to fight back against the wave of new enemies. With no other choice, you and your troops flee.

answer_2.outcome:
You order your Archers to take care of the incoming enemy troops. They quickly start to aim at those new enemies riding on horseback. Your Archers shoots once in range, taking advantage of their head start, as the incoming enemies are too focused on riding quickly to aim. You see those enemies fall as your Archers shoots them down.

STAMP

battle_1_decision_3.3.prompt:
After raiding the town, your troops gather in the town center, waiting for your next command. Before you can give any, you’re ambushed my a fleet of enemy soldiers. They’re quick, already aiming their bows at your men.
Who do you send first?

answer_1.outcome: With little time, you send your Archers to take down the enemies. However, their speed fails to match your enemies, leading to some of your Archers to get shot and die. In good news, your Archers get a couple hits in, giving enough time for the rest of your troop to draw back. Even though you’ve lost some men, you return home with some resources.
answer_1.outcome_2: Your Archers, quick on horseback, charge at the enemies. The speed and agility of your horses allows your men to evade the incoming arrows, as the enemies are too focused on your Archers to think about the rest of your troop. The Archers shoot down the enemies with no causalities on your side. However, you see your men grow tired, and with the resources in hand, it would continue to be difficult to fight while holding such items. So, you decide to return home with your loot.

answer_2.outcome:
With little time, you send your Shieldmen to the front. With their shields, they defend the rest of your troops from the incoming arrows. However, this isn’t able to withstand much longer, as the waves of arrows start to weaken the shield.
Your offensive soldiers rush to attack the enemy Archers, but with a lack of speed, some of your Shieldmen fall before they your troops can attack. 
Your troops are able to push back against the enemies, just long enough for you to order a withdrawal. You have enough resources, and it would make fighting harder with less men and more carry ons.
answer_2.outcome_2: Your Sheildmen quickly step to the front, defending the rest of your troops from the incoming arrows. With the enemy soldiers distracted, your offensive men jump onto horseback, taking advantage of the distraction to attack. The enemy soldiers fall one by one, until no more arrows threaten your Sheildmen. However, you see your men grow tired, and with the resources in hand, it would continue to be difficult to fight while holding such items. So, you decide to return home with your loot.

battle_1_decision_3.4.prompt:

Do you sacrifice your Shield Man or do you attack all together?

You send your one Shieldman to defend against the arrows. All the enemy soldiers laser focus on them, pelting them with arrows. Your Shieldman withstands the arrows until they start to wear-down, then break the shield. 
You and your group doesn’t stick around long enough to see them fatally shot, fleeing from the unequal fight without any resources.

answer_2.outcome:
You decide to take the risk and attack all together. Quickly, you realize you are no match for your enemies’ speed and tactics. Without order, one of your solider starts to defend, becoming a target for the enemy Archer’s arrows.

It spooks the horse, causing it to yank itself out of the hold of one of your soldiers. Before you could grab onto the steed, it had already ran off towards the enemies, avoiding their arrows and kicking at their numbers. Not even the best trained men can defend against the back-kick of a horse.
In the chaos, you see the uninjured and living enemy Archers flee from the area. One of your soldiers is able to control the horse, and you quickly raid the town with what you can carry.
The horse still looked shaken up, so you decide to withdraw your army from the Kingdom.
